title: The Complete Guide to Ghost Tours
content:
There's something irresistible about walking through a haunted location after dark, hearing stories of tragedy and unexplained phenomena while shadows shift in your peripheral vision. Ghost tours have become one of the fastest-growing segments of tourism, drawing millions of visitors each year to cities with dark histories and restless spirits. Whether you're a skeptic looking for entertainment or a true believer hoping for a genuine encounter, this guide covers everything you need to know before booking your first ghost tour.

What Is a Ghost Tour?

A ghost tour is a guided experience that takes you through locations with reported paranormal activity, tragic histories, or both. Unlike standard historical tours, ghost tours focus on the darker side of a location's past—murders, epidemics, executions, and the spirits said to remain. Most tours happen after dark, adding atmosphere to the storytelling. Your guide shares historical facts alongside witness accounts, local legends, and sometimes their own paranormal experiences. Some tours stick purely to storytelling, while others incorporate ghost hunting equipment and encourage guests to look for evidence themselves. The best ghost tours blend genuine history with compelling narrative. You'll learn real facts about the locations you visit while getting chills from the supernatural stories attached to them.

What Are the Different Types of Ghost Tours?

Not all ghost tours are the same. Understanding the different formats helps you choose the right experience.

Walking Tours

The most common format. A guide leads a group on foot through a neighborhood, stopping at multiple haunted locations along the way. Walking ghost tours typically last 90 minutes to two hours and cover 1-2 miles. They're ideal for exploring cities like New Orleans, Savannah, or Edinburgh where haunted sites cluster in historic districts. Walking tours offer the most intimate experience—you're standing exactly where events happened, often close enough to peer through windows or touch historic walls.

Bus or Trolley Tours

Comfortable and efficient for covering more ground. Bus and trolley tours work well in spread-out cities or when visiting locations outside walking distance. You'll typically make several stops to exit and explore, with storytelling happening both on the vehicle and at each site. These tours suit visitors with mobility concerns or those who prefer not to walk extensively at night.

Pub Crawl Ghost Tours

Combine paranormal history with local nightlife. Ghost tour pub crawls visit several haunted bars and taverns, sharing ghost stories at each stop while you enjoy a drink. These tours tend to be more social and lighthearted, though the historical content is often just as solid. Popular in cities with old tavern districts like London, Dublin, and Boston.

Paranormal Investigation Tours

The most immersive option. Instead of just hearing stories, you actively hunt for ghosts using equipment like EMF detectors, spirit boxes, and thermal cameras. Paranormal investigation tours often provide the equipment, though some let you bring your own. These tours often access areas closed to regular visitors and run longer—sometimes several hours. They're best for serious enthusiasts who want hands-on experience with ghost hunting techniques.

Cemetery Tours

Focused specifically on historic graveyards. Cemetery ghost tours share stories of notable burials, unusual headstones, and apparitions reported among the graves. Some cemetery tours happen during the day, focusing more on history and symbolism, while nighttime versions emphasize the paranormal. Cities like New Orleans and Savannah are famous for their atmospheric above-ground cemeteries.

What Should You Expect on Your First Ghost Tour?

Knowing what happens during a typical tour helps you prepare and get the most from the experience.

Before the Tour

You'll receive a meeting point and time when you book—usually a public location like a plaza, hotel lobby, or famous landmark. Arrive 10-15 minutes early. Tours start on time because they're timed around sunset and have multiple stops to hit. Most tour companies check you in by name. Some provide wristbands or stickers to identify paid guests. Group sizes vary from 10 to 40 people depending on the company and tour type.

During the Tour

Your guide introduces themselves and sets expectations. They'll explain the route, mention any rules (stay with the group, watch your step, no flash photography at certain stops), and often share their own paranormal experiences to establish credibility. The group then moves through the route, stopping at each significant location. Stops typically last 5-10 minutes. The guide tells the historical backstory first, then layers in the ghost stories and reported sightings. Good guides encourage questions and welcome guests to share their own experiences. Between stops, guides often continue storytelling or share additional context about the neighborhood's history.

The Atmosphere

Tours are designed to be atmospheric, not terrifying. Think campfire stories, not horror movies. Guides aim for entertaining and intriguing rather than genuinely frightening. That said, the combination of darkness, historical tragedy, and unexplained accounts creates real tension at times. Many guests report feeling watched, sensing cold spots, or noticing anomalies in photos they take during tours. Whether you attribute these to ghosts or psychology, they add to the experience. See our ghost photography tips for advice on capturing these moments.

After the Tour

Most tours end near the starting point or at a convenient location. Guides typically welcome additional questions and often recommend other local haunted spots worth visiting. Tipping your guide is customary—$5-10 per person is standard if you enjoyed the tour.

How Do You Choose the Right Ghost Tour?

With multiple tour companies operating in popular destinations, here's how to pick the best one. For more detail, read our guide on how to spot a bad ghost tour before you book.

Read Recent Reviews

Check Google, TripAdvisor, and booking platforms for reviews from the past few months. Look for comments about the specific guide, not just the company—guide quality makes or breaks a ghost tour. Pay attention to mentions of historical accuracy, storytelling ability, and group management.

Consider Group Size

Smaller groups (under 20 people) offer a more intimate experience. You can hear better, ask questions, and feel less like you're in a crowd. Larger tours are often cheaper but can feel impersonal. Private vs public ghost tours have different advantages worth considering.

Check What's Included

Some tours include extras like a drink at a haunted bar, access to a normally closed building, or ghost hunting equipment. Others are walking-only with no add-ons. Neither is better—just know what you're booking.

Match the Tour to Your Interest

History buff? Look for tours emphasizing documented events and architectural details. Paranormal enthusiast? Choose investigation-style tours. First-timer? Standard walking tours provide the best introduction.

Verify the Route

Some companies publish their exact stops; others keep them vague. If there's a specific location you want to visit—a famous haunted house or cemetery—confirm the tour includes it before booking.

What Should You Wear on a Ghost Tour?

Ghost tours are outdoor walking activities, usually at night. Dress accordingly. For detailed advice, see our complete guide on what to wear on a ghost tour. Wear comfortable walking shoes with good traction—historic districts often have uneven cobblestones, cracked sidewalks, and poor lighting. Dress in layers since temperatures drop after sunset, and you'll be standing still during storytelling stops. Dark clothing is practical for nighttime but not required. Skip anything that makes noise (jangling jewelry, swishy jackets) if you want to hear clearly and avoid disrupting the atmosphere.

What Should You Bring on a Ghost Tour?

Your phone serves triple duty as camera, flashlight, and something to capture potential EVPs (electronic voice phenomena). Some guests bring dedicated cameras or even ghost hunting apps, though their effectiveness is debatable. A small flashlight helps navigate uneven terrain during darker portions of the route. Water is smart for longer tours, especially in humid climates like New Orleans or Savannah. Leave large bags at your hotel—they slow you down and bump into other guests. Valuables are better secured elsewhere since you're walking through public areas at night, often in tourist-heavy zones.

When Is the Best Time to Book a Ghost Tour?

Time of Year

October is peak season for obvious reasons—Halloween atmosphere is everywhere, and many companies offer special extended tours or exclusive access during the month. The downside: tours book up fast and group sizes swell. Shoulder seasons (spring and fall) offer the best balance of comfortable weather, manageable crowds, and full tour schedules. Summer works but can be uncomfortably hot and humid in southern destinations. Winter tours have the shortest days (more darkness) and smallest crowds, but some companies reduce schedules or close entirely.

Time of Night

Most tours start between 7pm and 9pm, timed so the route happens after full dark. Earlier tours suit families with children; later tours tend to attract adults looking for a spookier atmosphere. Some companies offer late-night tours (10pm or 11pm start) that access locations after closing time or explore more intense content. These are typically not family-friendly.

Day of Week

Weekend tours fill up first. If your schedule is flexible, weekday tours often have smaller groups and more availability—sometimes at lower prices.

Special Considerations

Different travelers have different needs. Taking kids on ghost tours requires careful selection of family-friendly options. Solo ghost tours offer a surprisingly comfortable way to explore haunted cities alone. Ghost tours for couples make surprisingly good date nights. And if you're not sure about the whole ghost thing, ghost tours for skeptics explains why you don't need to believe to enjoy the experience. Prefer to explore at your own pace? Our comparison of ghost tours vs self-guided exploration helps you decide which approach fits your travel style.

How Much Should You Tip Your Ghost Tour Guide?

Tipping your ghost tour guide is customary in the United States. The standard tip is $5-10 per person if you enjoyed the tour. Exceptional guides who go above and beyond—answering extra questions, sharing personal experiences, or providing recommendations—deserve tips on the higher end. Tips matter because many ghost tour guides work as independent contractors or receive modest base pay. Your tip directly rewards good storytelling and historical knowledge. If you're traveling internationally, check local tipping customs since expectations vary by country.

Tips for Getting the Most Out of Your Ghost Tour

After hearing thousands of ghost stories across hundreds of tours, here's what separates memorable experiences from forgettable ones.

Stay Present

Put your phone away except when taking photos. The experience lives in the atmosphere, the guide's delivery, and your own senses. Guests who spend the whole tour filming often miss the actual stories.

Position Yourself Well

Stand near the guide at each stop—you'll hear better and see their expressions during dramatic moments. Avoid the back of the group where sound gets lost and latecomers shuffle in.

Ask Questions

Good guides love engaged guests. Ask about their personal experiences, the historical sources for stories, or details about locations you're curious about. Your questions often prompt the best off-script stories.

Keep an Open Mind

You don't have to believe in ghosts to enjoy a ghost tour. Treat it as entertainment with a history lesson attached. But staying open to the experience—noticing how you feel at certain locations, watching for anomalies—makes it more engaging than approaching with determined skepticism.

Take Photos

Shoot more than you think you need, especially in darker areas where your flash illuminates things you couldn't see. Many of the most famous "ghost photos" were taken by tourists who noticed something strange only when reviewing shots later.

Talk to Your Guide After

Most guides have more stories than time allows on the tour. If you're intrigued, stick around and chat—you'll often hear their best material.

Ready to Book Your First Ghost Tour?

The hardest part is choosing where to go. Cities build their reputations on different types of hauntings and historical tragedy. New Orleans offers voodoo, vampires, and centuries of French Quarter ghosts. Savannah claims more haunted locations per square mile than anywhere else in America. Edinburgh's underground vaults hide some of Scotland's darkest secrets. London spans Roman ghosts to Jack the Ripper. Salem's witch trial history draws visitors year-round. Each destination has its own character, its own tragedies, and its own restless spirits waiting to share their stories. Browse our destination guides to find the perfect haunted city for your first ghost tour—then book a tour and see what's really out there in the dark.
